message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hypertension puts pressure on the heart, causing left ventricular hypertrophy. This means an increase in the size of cardiac cells. Therefore, the answer is (C). Disordered growth of the cardiac cells (A) and decrease in cardiac cell size (B) are not common in hypertensive heart disease. Increase in the number of normal cardiac cells (D) is not a likely scenario in hypertensive heart disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Chronic hypertension can lead to left ventricular hypertrophy, which is characterized by an increase in cardiac cell size. Disordered growth of the cardiac cells is not a known mechanism for left ventricular hypertrophy. Decrease in cardiac cell size and an increase in the number of normal cardiac cells are not associated with left ventricular hypertrophy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Chronic hypertension can lead to left ventricular hypertrophy, which is an increase in cardiac cell size. Therefore, the most likely reason for the changes seen on echocardiography is an increase in cardiac cell size.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hypertension causes an increase in pressure in the heart, leading to an increase in cardiac workload and ultimately hypertrophy of the cardiac cells, resulting in an increase in size. Therefore, the most likely reason for the changes seen in the left ventricle is an increase in cardiac cell size.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of hypertension and echocardiography showing changes in the left ventricle point to left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH), which is characterized by an increase in cardiac cell size. Option A is incorrect as disordered growth of cardiac cells is not a recognized mechanism for LVH. Option B is incorrect, as a decrease in cardiac cell size is not associated with LVH. Option D is incorrect as an increase in the number of normal cardiac cells is not a recognized mechanism for LVH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The left ventricle changes suggest hypertrophy, which is the increase in size of cardiac cells. This is a common adaptation of the heart to hypertension. Disordered growth of cardiac cells would suggest a pathological condition, whereas a decrease in cardiac cell size would suggest atrophy, which is unlikely in this case. An increase in the number of normal cardiac cells, such as through exercise, would also be unlikely in a 70-year-old patient with hypertension, who may be less physically active.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has had hypertension for 20 years which can lead to left ventricular hypertrophy, indicating an increase in cardiac cell size. Disordered growth, decrease in cardiac cell size, and increase in the number of normal cardiac cells are not likely causes of left ventricular changes in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hypertension can cause an increase in workload on the heart, leading to an increase in cardiac cell size (hypertrophy). This change in the left ventricle can be seen on echocardiography. Disordered growth of the cardiac cells, decrease in cardiac cell size, and increase in number of normal cardiac cells are not commonly associated with hypertension.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hypertension causes an increase in workload on the heart, leading to hypertrophy and an increase in cardiac cell size. Option (A) is incorrect as there is no mention of disordered growth. Option (B) is incorrect as a decrease in cardiac cell size is not a known consequence of hypertension. Option (D) is also incorrect as an increase in the number of normal cardiac cells is unlikely to occur in response to hypertension.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only an increase in cardiac cell size (hypertrophy) is associated with hypertension. Disordered growth refers to neoplastic growth or abnormal cell proliferation, which is not seen in this case. A decrease in cardiac cell size is associated with atrophy and is not expected in a patient with hypertension. An increase in the number of normal cardiac cells is not a recognized mechanism of adaptation to hypertension.
